item.title: Survival camping isn't for everyone — so how would you go in the wilderness? Take the quiz to find out
item.description: For 18-year-old Rivi, knowing what gear to leave behind can be as important as knowing what to take with.

item.title: Rain brings relief across much of Victoria but the drought is 'certainly not over'
item.description: Dusty Victorian farms turn muddy as drenching rain brings much-needed relief.

item.title: Rose Byrne plays a mother on the edge in Mary Bronstein's If I Had Legs I'd Kick You
item.description: The Sydney-born movie star discusses how her creative partnership with If I had Legs I'd Kick You director Mary Bronstein has opened the Oscars conversation.

item.title: Inspection of Weona Park horse stud found several serious animal welfare issues, just weeks before public outcry
item.description: Investigators warned the "situation" at a horse stud in the state's south "is likely to [be] the next welfare issue hitting the news".

item.title: Horned 'devil' bee found in remote Goldfields prompts call for further research
item.description: The discovery of a new "lucifer" bee with devil-like horns sparks concerns over land clearing regulations in WA's Goldfields region.

item.title: Amid ongoing drought in South Australia, these women are redefining resilience
item.description: Dusty paddocks, with no grain crop to harvest, and scarce feed for the few animals left, is the reality of many South Australian farmers right now. Four women are redefining resilience and showing what it means to endure tough conditions despite it all.

item.title: Victorian farmer to auction father's vintage tractor collection
item.description: Tony Forrest reflects on his father's love of old tractors as he prepares them for sale.

item.title: Indonesian school kids poisoned by free school lunches
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: Aldo Revaldo taken to hospital with suspected poisoning
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: Accusations of secrecy, abuse of power fly as WA Labor wades through third term
item.description: Accusations of secrecy and abuse of process have been levelled at the Western Australian government this week on several fronts. Are they blips on the radar or signs WA Labor is under strain?

item.title: Wong won't put price tag on COP31 as final host decision looms
item.description: Foreign Minister Penny Wong has refused to say how much it would cost Australia to hold the COP31 climate conference, as negotiations over hosting rights enter the final stages.

item.title: Love of toys takes former retailer from Sydney's CBD to Blayney library
item.description: After a career in one of Sydney's busiest department stores, a retail expert takes her tricks of the trade to a toy library in central west NSW.

item.title: More coloured sand recalls prompt ACT to close 70 schools over asbestos concerns
item.description: Kmart has recalled four coloured sand products over concerns of asbestos contamination, prompting the ACT education department to close dozens more schools.

item.title: Government considers dramatic intervention to save Tomago smelter
item.description: The federal government is considering a power-purchase agreement with Tomago to supply electricity at a stable price, after warnings the smelter may need to close because of rising power costs.

item.title: Former MP Nick Dametto declares victory in Townsville mayoral by-election
item.description: Nick Dametto, a former Queensland MP, has won 61 per cent of the votes counted, succeeding in his campaign to become Townsville's next mayor.

item.title: Coalition plans to strip climate from energy operator's objectives
item.description: Emissions reduction would no longer be an objective of Australia's energy operator under a Coalition plan endorsed by the Nationals and Liberals, prioritising affordability and reliability over climate.

item.title: ACT closes 70 schools as more sand products recalled amid asbestos concerns
item.description: The ACT will close more schools after additional coloured sand products were recalled by Kmart and Target, while the schools that were shut on Friday will reopen on Monday.

item.title: From 'female Donald Trump' to 'Wacky' Marjorie — how Taylor Greene's alliance with the president crumbled
item.description: Once considered one of Donald Trump's most loyal soldiers, Marjorie Taylor Greene has found herself an outcast of the MAGA firm.

item.title: Renegades down Stars by four wickets as Devine sends down stunner in Scorchers win
item.description: The Renegades get the better of the Stars in the Melbourne derby, while Sophie Devine bowls one of the balls of the season in the Scorchers' defeat of the Strikers.

item.title: Zac Lomax released by Eels for 'opportunities outside NRL', fuelling speculation of R360 switch
item.description: Parramatta star Zac Lomax is released from the final three years of his NRL contract, fuelling speculation of a move to breakaway rugby competition R360.

item.title: Energy chiefs say net zero 'irreversible' even though bills unlikely to fall 'for a decade'
item.description: Amid swirling debate among conservative politicians over decarbonisation, energy bosses have warned against turning away from net zero despite cost pressures.

item.title: Why 'not just living for the weekend' may be a social media trend for good
item.description: Emma Dickeson says her "school night" adventures are about devoting time and attention to the things that energise you.

item.title: Laos methanol poisoning survivor 'turning grief into action'
item.description: A survivor of last year's Laos mass methanol poisoning has started a campaign to educate travellers on the dangers of the toxic form of alcohol.

item.title: The strange macho appeal of fossil fuels in a world struggling to reach net zero
item.description: The strange macho appeal of fossilised vegetation means that 30 years of annual United Nations meetings to stop the planet heating any more have been a bust.

item.title: Indian counterterrorism agency arrests alleged co-conspirator in Red Fort suicide bombing
item.description: India's National Investigation Agency says two men behind last week's deadly car blast in Delhi were from Kashmir, a region that has been a source of tension between India and Pakistan.

item.title: WA testing lab inundated by families' and retailers' concerns about asbestos-contaminated sand
item.description: Concerned families and retailers are inundating a materials testing laboratory with enquiries, since news broke that asbestos had been detected in decorative and coloured sand for children.

item.title: Sussan Ley scrabbling to retain leadership after net zero capitulation puts one advantage at risk
item.description: It was only a week ago that the moderates in the Liberal Party were flexing their muscle privately (and some publicly), threatening a divorce with the Nationals and to walk the plank if net zero was dumped. Neither threat ever materialised.

item.title: Operational dates for Northern Water project pushed out by several years
item.description: Completion of the South Australian government’s Northern Water desalination plant and water pipeline is now forecast to occur in 2032.

item.title: Numbers suggest England's Ashes preparation does not make a difference
item.description: Has England compromised its pre-Ashes preparation by playing only one three-day warm-up match against its own reserve team before the first Test in Perth? The numbers say no.

item.title: Police mental health unit under the spotlight after the deaths of 10 people
item.description: An officer who headed the NSW Police unit training the force in mental health responses once committed misconduct in a case where a mentally ill man was fatally shot by police.

item.title: Sam Kerr rested as Chelsea drops Women's Super League points
item.description: English champs Chelsea decide to rest Sam Kerr for their WSL clash against Liverpool but appear to pay the price with a 1-1 slip-up at Liverpool.

item.title: Maya Joint's fighting qualities praised in Billie Jean King Cup win over Brazil
item.description: Australia advances to the qualifying stage of the Billie Jean King Cup after Maya Joint and Kimberly Birrell dug deep to defeat Brazil and top their group.

item.title: Locals brace for timber industry job losses amid creation of Great Koala National Park
item.description: A third of Herons Creek’s population on the NSW mid north coast faces possible redundancy as the timber mill struggles to survive the logging moratorium to create the Great Koala National Park.

item.title: Jannik Sinner beats Carlos Alcaraz in ATP Finals in latest Sincaraz rivalry
item.description: Jannik Sinner has defeated world number one Carlos Alcaraz 7-6 (4), 7-5 in the ATP Finals title decider, defending his crown.

item.title: Groote Eylandt's unique rehabilitation program offers alternative to NT prison system amid record incarceration rates
item.description: As the NT's prison population soars to new highs, Anindilyakwa elders on Groote Eylandt are delivering a unique rehabilitation program that provides participants with physical and psycho-educational programs, as well as new skills and employment opportunities.

item.title: Unique rehabilitation program offers alternative to prison system
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: Esperance community fights for more change, a decade on from deadly bushfires
item.description: A decade on from bushfires that claimed four lives, this community says not enough has been done to ensure they are safe.

item.title: Iran begins cloud seeding to induce rain as it faces worst drought in decades
item.description: Cloud seeding involves spraying particles such as silver iodide and salt into clouds from aircraft to trigger rain.

item.title: Calls for greater education as growers in WA's south-west brace for polyphagous shot-hole borer
item.description: Growers in this major food bowl are nervous for their future, as the state focuses its shot-hole borer efforts on outer-Perth.

item.title: South Africa beat India by 30 runs in low-scoring first Test boilover
item.description: South Africa upsets India on a turning pitch at Eden Gardens, with spinner Simon Harmer taking eight wickets in a man-of-the-match performance for the World Test Champions.

item.title: Koala mapping near Mudgee discovers strong population and ideal habitat
item.description: Scientists mapping koala habitat in the NSW central west find it is larger than previously thought, but concerns remain over expansion plans at a nearby coal mine.

item.title: Ireland celebrates after Troy Parrott secures last-second World Cup qualifier victory over Hungary
item.description: Ireland keeps its hopes alive of making the World Cup finals for the first time since 2002 with a stunning comeback.

item.title: When is the 2025 AFL draft? Here's your guide to bidding, trades and the official pick order
item.description: Another AFL draft has arrived, offering dozens of teenage footballers the chance to realise their dreams. Here is everything you need to know.

item.title: From Blue Poles to Gina Rinehart, the most controversial artworks in Australia
item.description: Art can stir strong feelings in people, both good and bad. These artworks fell in the latter, provoking great controversy in Australia, and telling us a lot about who we are as a nation.

item.title: Sam Konstas picked to open for Prime Minister's XI against England in Canberra
item.description: Sam Konstas will return to the scene where he made his case for Test selection last summer, with the axed opener given a chance to face England with the Prime Minister's XI.

item.title: Paralympic gold medal winner Paige Greco dies, aged 28
item.description: Australian Paralympian Paige Greco, who won Australia's first gold medal of the 2020 Tokyo Paralympic Games, has died aged 28.

item.title: China's seafood import rules behind a partial closure of Tasmania's rock lobster fishery
item.description: The Tasmanian government closed two zones within the state's rock lobster fishery just hours after the commercial season opened. The closure is in response to concerns about an antibiotic being used by salmon companies and the rock lobster industry's reputation in overseas markets.

item.title: Why the ACT has gone further than other jurisdictions in closing schools over coloured sand asbestos concerns
item.description: The ACT has closed 70 schools over the coloured sand asbestos scare. Why is it the only jurisdiction to do so?

item.title: Mackay Base Hospital expansion paused as contractor withdraws from site
item.description: Brisbane contractor BESIX Watpac will leave the Mackay Base Hospital construction site in Queensland as a report finds the cost of a 128-bed expansion has more than doubled.

item.title: Donald Trump calls on Republicans to vote to release Epstein files
item.description: President Donald Trump has called on his fellow Republicans in Congress to vote for the release of files related to the late convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Sharing COP presidency with Türkiye 'not an option', says Albanese
item.description: As Chris Bowen lands in Belém with the clock ticking on a resolution, Anthony Albanese says the rules against co-presidency for the COP are clear.

item.title: Should I kick my diet soft-drink habit? Where do I start?
item.description: You don't have to give up diet soft drinks altogether. But being mindful of how much soft drink you drink, and how often, can help you make healthier choices.

item.title: Anthony Albanese writes to states, telling them to rein in public hospital spending
item.description: Health ministers are furious with a letter from the prime minister demanding they rein in spending if they want a public hospital funding deal honoured.

item.title: Child poverty, homelessness hit new highs in mining-rich WA
item.description: Rates of child poverty in WA have doubled in a decade, but there is a severe lack of crisis accommodation, prompting experts to call on governments to do more.

item.title: Queensland government denies dingoes could be kept as pets under contentious reclassification
item.description: Queensland is considering changes that would remove restrictions on keeping dingoes and while the government says that will not mean people can keep them as pets, experts fear it could be an unintended outcome.

item.title: Caroline Flack: Search for the Truth raises questions about assault charges and British tabloid ethics
item.description: In a two-part series, the mother of television presenter Caroline Flack examines the final months of her daughter's life and what she believes to be the mishandling of the criminal case against her daughter.

item.title: Late Yolŋu leader Paul Gurrumuruwuy Wunungmurra honoured with PhD for anthropology, filmmaking
item.description: World-renowned anthropologist, filmmaker and Arnhem Land Indigenous leader Paul Gurrumuruwuy Wunungmurra has become the first Yolŋu person to be honoured for his work with a PhD for original research.

item.title: Asbestos sand contamination also affecting New Zealand, after 70 Australian schools close
item.description: After asbestos was found in a range of coloured sand, early childhood centres and schools in Australia and New Zealand are hurrying to dispose of potentially contaminated products.

item.title: Tasmanian private mental health service The Hobart Clinic reopens after 17-day closure
item.description: A $2 million transitional funding injection from the Tasmanian government has allowed The Hobart Clinic to treat patients for six more months while it comes up with a sustainable business model.

item.title: South African man who attended Neo-Nazi rally outside NSW parliament has visa cancelled
item.description: The federal government has revoked the visa of a man who attended the far-right National Socialist Network protest at NSW's parliament house.

item.title: Australian beef producers welcome end to Donald Trump's import tariffs
item.description: Shoppers at home and abroad are unlikely to see any immediate change in the price of Australian beef as tariffs that did little to curb demand in the first place are lifted.

item.title: Quick and easy summer dinners
item.description: The busy end of year calls for simple dinners that are ready in 35 minutes or less.

item.title: Dozens of Canberra schools to reopen, 25 remain closed over coloured sand asbestos contamination concerns
item.description: Dozens of public schools in the ACT will reopen or partially open on Tuesday, but 25 remain closed for all students.

item.title: Black swan 'Jandal' released in Alice Springs after recovering from suspected dog attack
item.description: An unlikely patient in Alice Springs is returned to the water treatment ponds two weeks after being found injured from a suspected dog attack.

item.title: Monday Finance with Alan Kohler
item.description: News from the world of finance and business. Top stories in text, video and audio. Business video news bulletin. Features and analysis.

item.title: Brendan Doggett poised for Test cricket debut in first Ashes Test against England
item.description: Fast bowler Brendan Doggett says he learned he could make a Test debut while waiting to bat in South Australia's Sheffield Shield run chase last week against Tasmania.

item.title: Mary Fowler's resilience in face of mental health struggles hailed by Matildas coach Joe Montemurro
item.description: Mary Fowler is unlikely to be back on the pitch with the Matildas until next year at the earliest, but coach Joe Montemurro is making sure to stay in close contact.

item.title: Several Tasmanian non-government schools closed, others partially closed due to coloured sand recall
item.description: At least six non-government schools have closed, and six others partially closed on Monday due to the national recall of coloured sand products over asbestos contamination, with others slated for closure on Tuesday.

item.title: Bangladesh's ousted PM Sheikh Hasina sentenced to death for student crackdown
item.description: A Bangladesh court has sentenced ousted prime minister Sheikh Hasina to death after finding her guilty of crimes against humanity.

item.description: Sarah Ferguson presents Australia's premier daily current affairs program, delivering agenda-setting public affairs journalism and interviews that hold the powerful to account. Plus political analysis from Laura Tingle.

item.title: Pat Cummins completes bowling session before first Ashes Test
item.description: Australia captain Pat Cummins completes a full bowling session at training just four days before the start of the Ashes.

item.title: Donald Trump’s “Epstein Files” problem
item.description: Sarah Ferguson presents Australia's premier daily current affairs program, delivering agenda-setting public affairs journalism and interviews that hold the powerful to account. Plus political analysis from Laura Tingle.

item.title: Rio Tinto scraps $215m research centre and BioIron product after decade of development
item.description: Mining giant Rio Tinto scraps a $215 million research centre and green steel project touted last year as a key staging ground for the world's net zero transition.

item.title: Opposition Leader Sussan Ley guarantees she will remain leader until next election
item.description: Opposition Leader Sussan Ley may be under siege, but says she has no doubts she will remain party leader until the next federal election.

item.title: Australian man Johnson Wen jailed after grabbing Ariana Grande at Wicked: For Good premiere
item.description: Johnson Wen, who is alleged to have disrupted other global sports events and concerts, has shown "a pattern of behaviour", according to a Singapore court judge.

item.title: BBC 'determined to fight' looming Trump lawsuit over speech edit
item.description: The US president says he could sue the British national broadcaster for as much as $US5 billion.

item.title: Japan attempts to cool tensions with China as diplomatic spat over Taiwan continues
item.description: Tokyo has sent a senior foreign ministry official to Beijing to try and ease tensions, that have seen threats made against Japan's prime minister.

item.title: At least 18 people killed in Indonesian landslides as rescue efforts continue to find more than 30 others missing
item.description: Multiple landslides have engulfed communities in Central Java, with hundreds of emergency workers involved in the rescue operations.

item.title: The Ashes quiz: Test your knowledge ahead of the 2025/26 Ashes Test
item.description: Ahead of the 2025/26 Ashes series getting underway on November 21 in Perth, test out your knowledge in our fiendish Ashes quiz.

item.title: What price power? How electricity became a political weapon
item.description: A decade and a half after an energy company CEO outlined his greatest fears for Australia's economic future — no carbon price — the nation again appears set for a renewed battle over climate policy and power generation.

item.title: Nirvana’s MTV Unplugged: How a near-disaster became an iconic live performance
item.description: It was nearly a disaster, but Nirvana going acoustic for MTV ended up being one of the most iconic live performances ever and cemented Kurt Cobain as a tortured genius.

item.title: Lost at sea: The harrowing hours of the deadliest Sydney to Hobart race
item.description: The fleet of the 1998 Sydney to Hobart yacht race set sail from the harbour city, unaware they were travelling directly into the path of a huge storm and unrelenting swell that would throw the race into disarray and claim six lives.

item.title: Renewable energy generators need to cut supply to stay sustainable. Here's why
item.description: When there is an oversupply of solar and wind power, energy producers are paying more to deliver electricity to households than they get paid. Here's what we know about how it affects you.

item.title: Inside the AFL's infamous 2020 'COVID draft' as teams and players battled impacts of lockdowns
item.description: It is the AFL draft that has become a cautionary tale to clubs. Five years on from the infamous 2020 draft, here is the story on the tumultuous year from those involved in it.

item.title: 'Aussie Cossack' Simeon Boikov says staff at Russia's Sydney consulate are trying to push him out
item.description: Simeon Boikov, the pro-Putin propagandist hiding from authorities in the Russian consulate in Sydney, launches an extraordinary attack on his hosts, saying they are subjecting him to "prison-like conditions" in a bid to "push me out".

item.title: The long road to the House of Representatives vote on the Epstein files
item.description: The US House of Representatives is poised to take a significant step in the mammoth saga of the so-called "Epstein files". Here's how we got there.

item.title: Rio Tinto pauses plans for $3.7b lithium mine but Serbians remain concerned
item.description: Rio Tinto may have mothballed its proposed $3.6 billion lithium project in Serbia's Jadar Valley, but opponents have vowed to keep fighting until the mining giant leaves the area for good.

item.title: Figures show areas with high Indigenous populations have more poker machines
item.description: New figures show there are 50 per cent more pokies in areas with an Indigenous population of at least 10 per cent. Gambling groups say it is "not surprising".

item.title: Queensland parents divided on recall of decorative sand over contamination concerns
item.description: While some Queensland parents are angered by the nationwide recall of coloured sand that may have traces of asbestos, others are less concerned.

item.title: Businesses urge Labor and Coalition to 'work together' on environmental reform
item.description: The next few days are viewed as critical to landing a deal on the proposed reforms to update the EPBC Act, amid hopes the Liberals will be more motivated to bolster their environmental credentials after ditching net zero.

item.title: Slain paramedic Steven Tougher's wife speaks out on mental health, a year after killer was detained
item.description: One year after Steven Tougher's killer was found not criminally responsible due to mental impairment, his wife says she has learnt to accept it.

item.title: Tasmanian duo Beau Webster, Jake Weatherald vie for Ashes Test spot in Perth
item.description: Teammates for Tasmania, Beau Webster and Jake Weatherald will be locked in a battle to play for Australia in the first Test of the Ashes.

item.title: Alex Greenwich moves to fast track medicinal cannabis driving reforms in NSW
item.description: Independent Sydney MP Alex Greenwich says it is time to "get the ball rolling" on medical cannabis reforms in NSW.

item.title: Landowner concerned about site rehabilitation as Murray Zircon shuts operations
item.description: A mine in South Australia's Murray Mallee is ceasing operations and says it will rehabilitate the site back to its original condition. However, the site's owner says the land will never get back to what it was before mining.

item.title: Darebin asks AFL for lifeline as club faces financial pressure to stay in VFLW
item.description: Darebin nurtured AFLW stars Daisy Pearce and Darcy Vescio, but financial constraints could force the independent club out of the VFLW.

item.title: Lleyton Hewitt's Davis Cup win over Rodger Federer saw off AFL switch
item.description: An epic Davis Cup win over Roger Federer in 2003 convinced Australian tennis great Lleyton Hewitt to not go ahead with a stunning career change. Two-time grand slam champion Hewitt is one of seven inductees into the Sport Australia Hall of Fame.

item.title: TPG Telecom says Sydney person died after outdated phone software blocked Triple Zero calls
item.description: TPG Telecom says a Sydney customer died after outdated software blocked a Samsung phone from making Triple Zero calls.

item.title: Emotional scenes at Moss Vale site hearing over proposed plastics factory
item.description: Normally confined to four walls, the Land and Environment Court holds a site hearing in the NSW Southern Highlands to hear residents' concerns about a proposed recycling plant.

item.title: When is the ARIAs awards ceremony? Where can I watch it?
item.description: The Australian music industry awards will be celebrating some of the best acts in the country this week.

item.title: Donald Trump says he will sign bill to release Epstein files if it passes Congress
item.description: The bill — to direct the US Justice Department to release its documents about late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein — now looks set to sail through the House of Representatives.

item.title: Coloured sand is being disposed of across the country due to asbestos contamination concerns. How much risk does it actually pose?
item.description: Dozens of schools remain closed in the ACT, Tasmania and South Australia today as the clean-up and disposal of potentially asbestos-laced coloured sand continues. What risk does it actually pose?

item.title: Jake Paul and Anthony Joshua's boxing match is a dangerous betrayal of the sport
item.description: Nobody plays at boxing. But Jake Paul's upcoming contest against a bona fide, former two-time unified heavyweight champion of the world smacks of a game about to go seriously wrong.

item.title: Asbestos scare widens as more than 350 SA schools detect recalled sand
item.description: The number of public education sites in South Australia that have reported coloured sand linked to an asbestos contamination scare rises above 350, but authorities say there is no plan for closures at this stage.

item.title: More schools reopen in Canberra on Wednesday as coloured sand clean-up continues
item.description: More schools have reopened in Canberra, with a list of current closures to be updated today.

item.title: AFL draft 2025 club by club preview: Your team's picks and potential targets
item.description: With the AFL draft just around the corner, see which picks each club has to work with and the players they could select.

item.title: Cyclists, pedestrians diverted to Causeway amid closure of Boorloo Bridge in Perth
item.description: The Boorloo Bridge, which connects Perth's inner southern suburbs with the CBD, will remain closed until Thursday after lighting fell from the structure.

item.title: Category two cyclone predicted off NT coast by Thursday
item.description: The Bureau of Meteorology has issued its first forecast track map for a tropical low over the NT, showing the system is expected to strengthen into a category two cyclone by Thursday night.

item.title: Health expert, football pioneer, historian, and mental health advocate honoured as ACT Australians of the Year
item.description: This year's ACT Australian of the Year honours go to a refugee health expert, football pioneer, historical guide and mental health advocate.

item.title: Sikh communities celebrate Gurmesh Singh's election as NSW Nationals leader
item.description: Gurmesh Singh's election as the new leader of the NSW Nationals is being hailed as great news for Indian Sikh communities across the state.

item.title: The Australian music groups celebrating major milestone anniversaries in 2025
item.description: Improvising with headlights, a sold-out debut and championing new music are some of the impacts these Australian music groups have made in their decades-long existence.

item.title: Gippsland's Willem Duursma set to become fourth family member to join AFL/AFLW
item.description: Willem Duursma's dancing feet could carry him all the way to the number-one pick at tomorrow night's AFL National Draft.

item.title: Eli Katoa to miss 2026 NRL season after Melbourne Storm star's brain surgery
item.description: Melbourne Storm star Eli Katoa will miss the 2026 NRL season as he continues his recovery from head knocks that forced him to have brain surgery.

item.title: Vanuatu council repeals law banning menstruating women from selling food
item.description: A Vanuatu provincial government says it will repeal parts of its new bylaw banning menstruating women from preparing and selling food at markets and roadside stalls after the decision sparked a public outcry.

item.title: Asbestos contamination of children's sand was a fluke discovery in an Australian lab
item.description: An Australian lab discovered asbestos in children's play sand by chance and regulators only found out about it because of a podcast interview, the ABC can reveal.

item.title: Inside The Hood Contender, Australia's controversial amateur fighting competition trying to save men's lives
item.description: The organiser of this fight club says it saves lives. But critics say it is putting young men at serious risk.

item.title: CSIRO to cut up to 350 research jobs in major overhaul
item.description: After 440 positions were slashed last year, the CSIRO has announced more staff cuts across the country in a bid to remain financially viable.

item.title: Brisbane Lions recruit Neasa Dooley wanting to add more Irish success in AFLW preliminary final against Carlton Blues
item.description: No stranger to the big stage, Brisbane's Neasa Dooley wants a piece of what her fellow Irish imports have been selling.

item.title: What it's like being a male early childhood educator amid the childcare crisis
item.description: While the childcare crisis has left me concerned about my own child's safety, as a male early childhood educator, I'm also worried about the future of men in the sector, writes Ben.

item.title: Parents in 'childcare desert' left scrambling as Playtime Preschool enters voluntary administration
item.description: One of the few childcare operators in Broken Hill has closed its doors indefinitely with 24 hours warning after entering voluntary administration.

item.title: Defence inspector inadvertently omitted 10 consultations held with NACC chief Paul Brereton
item.description: A previous disclosure that the head of the federal corruption watchdog had been consulted 11 times has been corrected to 21.

item.title: Victorian Liberals' first female leader Jess Wilson must prove the party is worth fighting for
item.description: Victoria's first female Liberal Party leader is facing a gargantuan task to unite her party and prove the opposition is worth voting for, Richard Willingham writes.

item.title: BlueScope AGM held in shadow of Port Kembla steelworks fatality, minute’s silence held
item.description: Shareholders and executives observe a minute's silence at BlueScope's AGM for the young worker killed at Port Kembla steelworks.

item.title: Sydney waste water likely origin of debris on Central Coast beaches
item.description: Sydney Water is working to determine the source of high levels of grease and oil that caused debris balls to wash up on beaches across Sydney and the Central Coast.

item.title: COP30 decision by South Korea to shut down coal a reckoning for Australian exports
item.description: In a move that has been welcomed by climate campaigners, South Korea has vowed to phase out coal, sparking a warning for Australian exporters.

item.title: Numerous Tasmanian public, Catholic and independent schools to close from Wednesday
item.description: More than 50 Tasmanian schools will either close or be partially closed from Wednesday in response to ongoing public health concerns relating to asbestos in coloured sand.

item.title: Remote Aboriginal community of Tjuntjuntjara challenges local government election result
item.description: A remote Aboriginal corporation lodges a formal dispute over the outcome of a local government election decided by just one vote.

item.title: Senator Fatima Payman calls on prime minister to denounce online trolls
item.description: After the man who threatened her life via email was sentenced in court earlier this week, Senator Fatima Payman is being targeted by online abuse.

item.title: Most restrictive abortion bill in the US being considered
item.description: Restrictions on IUDs and IVF and decades of imprisonment for having an abortion could become the reality for some women living in South Carolina if the legislation passes.

item.title: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese heralds WA gallium project as 'game changing'
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese visits the future West Australian gallium processing plant site, central to the United States critical minerals deal, heralding it as a "game changing" project.

item.title: Public hospitals wasting $1.2b a year and hindered by 'bogus budgets', Grattan Institute says
item.description: A new report recommends Australia’s public hospitals stop wasting money and adopt efficiency measures seen in other countries amid governmental tensions over a new funding deal.

item.title: Poland says Russian intelligence likely behind railway sabotage
item.description: Polish authorities say "everything indicates" Russian involvement in a blast along a railway line used to transport goods to Ukraine, as they identify two people believed to be responsible.

item.title: Britain's MI5 spy service issues alert to MPs over Chinese espionage threat
item.description: MI5 has warned that Chinese agents attempt to collect information and influence activity, posing the latest spy threat to the nation.

item.title: Japan warns citizens in China to be careful as diplomatic spat continues over Taiwan
item.description: Authorities have told Japanese people in China to avoid large crowds, as tensions between Tokyo and Beijing continue to simmer.

item.title: Roblox promises age checks as Australia's under-16 social media ban looms
item.description: The company says age verification checks will start in early December, around the same time Australia's social media ban for under-16s is set to come into effect.

item.title: Jess Wilson is the Victorian Liberals’ survival strategy. Are federal Liberals listening?
item.description: The Liberals in two big Australian states are realigning themselves — shifting to what Sussan Ley once described as the sensible centre.

item.title: How the Nintendo Wii's remote control changed gaming — one strike at a time
item.description: Innovative motion controls and accessible design made the Nintendo Wii one of the most popular consoles of all time.

item.title: Booker Prize quiz: Test your knowledge of the prestigious book award
item.description: The prestigious Booker Prize, worth $100,000, announced its 2025 winner last week. Do you remember who won? Test your knowledge of the world's favourite book awards with our quiz.

item.title: Dud superannuation options could cost retirees up to $205,000, Super Consumers warns
item.description: Superannuation products that fail the federal government's performance test are still offered to those already retired at a potentially huge cost, according to the consumer advocate.

item.title: Australia's weapons programs exposed in defence industry cyber attacks
